Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Teams: Opto-plasmonic Photodetectors for Low-Cost Tele/Data Communications Beyond 5G
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potentials of this I-Corps project include realization of ultra-fast optical receivers for applications in tele and data communication networks and centers both as in backbone infrastructure, and in end-user usage. This project provides unique technological advancements that circumvent traditional limits in speed of operation and in energy usage by taming the collective response of clouds of electrons in response to excitation - known as opto-plasmonic devices (OPD) - resulting in much more sensitive, high speed, and low power-consumption devices which convert optical signals to electrical ones, performing a crucial step in information transport. This reduces the energy cost-per-bit of information, helping Photonics Integrated Circuit (PIC) technology to become mainstream for general public use in applications such as in affordable ultra-high-speed Internet, high-capacity Internet-of-Things (IoT), and energy-saving cloud data storage and processing. Notably, this project contributes to the technological leadership of the US in the multi-billion dollar global communications markets, by generating advanced technical know-how and intellectual property, holding the key in manufacturing of new OPDs. Successful completion of this project results in a business opportunity for several sustainable jobs for electrical and optical engineers with potential for exponential growth in line with increasing demand for data communication.

This I-Corps project produces market-ready high-speed photodetector technology based on Indium Phosphide material system that are i) capable of operation in tele/data communication rates of more than 200 Gbits/sec, which is six times faster than state-of-the-art, and ii) compatible with Silicon Photonics technology through a heterogeneous integration with silicon. Specifically, this product solves a bottleneck in high-speed operation of Silicon Photonics Integrated Circuits that rely on Germanium-based photodetectors as their optical receiver. For this product to be commercially ready, research and development plan includes major milestones of a) producing a stand-alone side-illuminated InP-based high speed photodetector compatible with optical communication wavelengths, and b) integration of the developed InP-based optical receiver into a Si-Photonics integrated circuit. Prototyping work will be done using NSF-supporting fabrication facilities, but volume production feasibility will be demonstrated by utilizing a fab-less model and using existing silicon foundry services across the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

The backbone optical communication infrastructure is the workhorse of data transmission inter- and intra-data centers. Energy efficient and high capacity optical systems are in great demand, but high in price and low in supply. The advent of Photonics Integrated Circuits (PICs) has provided an economical solution to the supply and demand problem. A PIC is comprised of multiple optical components such as modulators, lasers, detectors, multiplexers and demultiplexers, and attenuators, all integrated in a single chip.

As of 2019 the PIC has a total available market (TAM) size of $8 Billion, with an expected compound annual growth rate of ~%28 up to 2025. The serviceable available market (SAM) of Optical Communications is $3 Billion in size, and specifically, our Serviceable Obtainable Market (SOM) of optical detectors is $1 Billion. 

Through this project, the team Nanograss Photonics, comprised of Dr. Pouya Dianat (Entrepreunial Lead), Dr. Bahram Nabet (Technical Lead), and Mr. Ed Hammel (Industry Mentor), participated in an intensive 7-week I-Corps program to conduct market viability study for their academically-developed Opto-plasmonic Device (OPD) technology. Market validation was performed through a comprehensive year-long customer discovery process completed by the team, during which more than 200 customer interviews were conducted by sight visits, attendance of global trade shows, and referrals. As a main outcome of this project, a product-market fit was identified based on the pain points of the customers.

Mainly, OPD technology is a strong contender as a photodetector in the PIC market. The team has developed a revolutionary family of photonic hardware, particularly a high-performing photodetector that addresses the supply-chain bottleneck for low latency, high bandwidth, long range, low power receiver modules used by data centers and cloud service providers. The project removes design constraint for hardware system integrators seeking to increase reliability, power efficiency, and range of their products. OPDs replace legacy avalanche photodiodes that need to be fabricated on expensive substrates, while achieving better performance.

Throughout this project, the team secured commercial early adopters for the OPD technology, developed a business model that included identification of key activities, required resources, and partnerships essential for a successful commercialization plan.

The team tested the learnings from this project through several presentations and participations in business pitch panels and competitions. These include:

 

  1. SPIE Startup Challenge 2019 Pitch Competition -  Semifinalist: (See here: https://spie.org/about-spie/press-room/press-release-archive/2019-spie-startup-challenge-semi-finalists-to-showcase-photonics-innovations-in-healthcare-lasers-wearables-and-iot-?SSO=1)
  2. Singh Center for Nanotechnology Innovation Seed Grant 2019 - Winner
  3. Start-up Global Program (Spring 2019) by Garage+ - A 10-day all-expenses-paid residency program in Taipei, supported by Taiwanese Epoch Foundation for a curated list of matches with potential Taiwanese partners. The program included free exhibition of Nanograss technology at Computex 2019 in Taipei, Taiwan.
  4. AUTM Eastern Region Meeting showcase "Pitch, Please! Positioning University Start-ups for Success Start-up?s? October 2019 - Finalist (See here: https://autm.net/events/region-meetings/eastern-region/2019/event-info)
  5. Luminate Lightning Round 2019 - Finalist. An accelerator program supported by Nextcorp and New York State (See here: https://luminate.org/)
  6. SPIE Startup Challenge 2020 - Semifinalist (See here: https://spie.org/industry-resources/industry-events/spie-startup-challenge/2020-semi-finalists)
  7. NASA iTech Ignite the Night pitch competition - Finalist (See here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZjqHmOtjX_g)
  8. 2020 NCET2 Virtual Startup Pitches to NCET2 Corporate Members and Startup Development Officer - Finalist (See here: https://ncet2.org/)

 

As a result of this project the team has moved forward in commercializing the OPD technology through Nanograss Photonics as a limited liability corporation. Based on the learnings of this project, the entrepreneurial lead of the project, Dr. Pouya Dianat, subsequently submitted a National Science Foundation Small Business Innovation Research Phase I proposal that was funded in August 2020.
